value: Eskihisar, literally "the old fortress", which gave the village its name

, on the northern coast of the Gulf of İzmit. Located just east of the
of almost boundless concrete jungle that is
, you are likely only here just to take the ferry across the Gulf to
side, but, provided you have some time to spare, you could do worse than stopping by a little.
, take D100 highway to east. Follow 'Eskihisar' signs once you left the suburbs of Istanbul behind and crossed the provincial boundary of
normally take about an hour from central parts of
, but the highway is almost always congested, at least in parts, unless you are driving between late at night and just after sunrise.
The very frequent minibuses plying the route between Gebze and Harem, Istanbul's main bus station on the Asian Side (and easily connected to Sirkeci in the
by frequent ferries), may be useful for getting to Eskihisar.
; 1.50 TL pp) depart from Haydarpaşa station in Istanbul's

, making the route in roughly an hour. From Gebze station, Eskihisar is about 30 minutes away on foot. Minibuses may also be available.

However, as of 2013, Gebze station receives no trains from no directions (and even the tracks themselves are absent in the station), as extensive rail rebuilding takes place all around in northwestern Turkey, in preparation for the high-speed link between Istanbul and Ankara. Expect this to continue at least until 2014.

value: Osman Hamdi Bey Museum in Eskihisar
directions=northeast of ferry harbour, on the hill overlooking the sea
directions=on the waterfront street; very near the ferry harbour
content=A renovated white wooden Victorian mansion that wouldn't be out of place in the
. Formerly owned by, and dedicated to, Osman Hamdi Bey (1842-1910), the founder of the
and one of the earliest modern Turkish painters.

There are some restaurants on the shore to the left of the ferry jetty.
) in the streets to the left of the ferry jetty.

value: Your most likely scenario to arrive in Eskihisar to take the

across the Gulf of Izmit. Ferries are quite frequent and take about 40-45 minutes to reach the other side. While passengers without a vehicle pay 2.80 TL/person, flat fare for cars is 45 TL one-way, i.e. it is not dependent on how many people are riding in the car. Larger vehicles pay substantially more.
